s0001: Empress Dowager Lü was Gao Zu's consort from his humble days; she gave birth to Emperor Xiaohui and her daughter Grand Empress Dowager Lu Yuan.
s0002: When Gao Zu became King of Han, he obtained Consort Qi of Dingtao, whom he loved and favored; she gave birth to King Yin of Zhao, Ruyi.
s0003: Emperor Xiaohui as a person was benevolent and weak; Gao Zu considered he did not resemble him and constantly wished to depose the Crown Prince and install Consort Qi's son Ruyi, who resembled him.
s0004: Consort Qi was favored and constantly followed the superior east of the passes, weeping day and night, wishing to have her son replace the Crown Prince.
s0005: Empress Lü was older and constantly remained behind on guard duty, rarely seeing the superior, and grew increasingly estranged.
s0006: After Ruyi was installed as King of Zhao, he nearly replaced the Crown Prince several times; they relied on the great ministers to争 for it, as well as the Marquis of Liu's strategy, and the Crown Prince was able to avoid being deposed.
s0007: Empress Lü as a person was firm and resolute; she assisted Gao Zu in settling all under Heaven, and many of the great ministers who were executed owed much to Empress Lü's strength.
s0008: Empress Lü had two elder brothers, both of whom served as generals.
s0009: The eldest brother Lord Zhou Lü died in service; they enfeoffed his son Lü Tai as Marquis of Li and his son Chan as Marquis of Jiao;
s0010: the next elder brother Lü Shizhi was Marquis of Jiancheng.
s0011: On the jiachen day of the fourth month in the twelfth year of Gao Zu, he died at Changle Palace; the Crown Prince inherited the title as Emperor.
s0012: At this time Gao Zu had eight sons: the eldest son Fei was Emperor Xiaohui's elder brother by a different mother; Fei was King of Qi;
s0013: the rest were all Emperor Xiaohui's younger brothers—Consort Qi's son Ruyi was King of Zhao, Consort Bo's son Heng was King of Dai, various consorts' sons—Hui was King of Liang, You was King of Huaiyang, Chang was King of Huainan, and Jian was King of Yan.
s0014: Gao Zu's younger brother Jiao was King of Chu; his nephew Bi was King of Wu.
s0015: The non-Liu meritorious minister, son of Lord Fan Wu Rui, Chen, was King of Changsha.
s0016: Empress Lü most resented Consort Qi and her son the King of Zhao, so she ordered Consort Qi imprisoned in the Eternal Lanes and summoned the King of Zhao.
s0017: After the envoy went three times, Zhao Prime Minister Marquis of Jianping Zhou Chang said to the envoy: "The High Emperor entrusted the King of Zhao to me; the King of Zhao is young.
s0018: I have secretly heard the Empress Dowager resents Consort Qi and wishes to summon the King of Zhao to execute them together; I dare not send the king.
s0019: Moreover, the king is also ill and cannot obey the edict."
s0020: Empress Lü was greatly enraged and sent men to summon the Zhao Prime Minister.
s0021: The Zhao Prime Minister was summoned to Chang'an, and she then sent men again to summon the King of Zhao.
s0022: The king came but had not yet arrived.
s0023: Emperor Xiaohui was compassionate and benevolent; knowing the Empress Dowager was angry, he personally welcomed the King of Zhao at Bashang, entered the palace with him, and personally stayed close to the King of Zhao in daily activities and meals.
s0024: The Empress Dowager wished to kill him but could not find an opportunity.
s0025: In the twelfth month of the first year of Emperor Xiaohui, the emperor went out at dawn to practice archery.
s0026: The King of Zhao was young and could not rise early.
s0027: The Empress Dowager heard he was alone and sent someone with poisoned wine for him to drink.
s0028: At dawn, Emperor Xiaohui returned; the King of Zhao was already dead.
s0029: Thereupon they moved King You of Huaiyang to be King of Zhao.

s0031: The Empress Dowager then cut off Consort Qi's hands and feet, gouged out her eyes, seared her ears, made her drink a muting drug, had her reside in the privy, and named her 'Human Pig.'
s0032: After several days, she summoned Emperor Xiaohui to observe the Human Pig.
s0033: Emperor Xiaohui saw her, inquired, and then knew it was Consort Qi; he then wept loudly, consequently fell ill, and for over a year could not rise.
s0034: He sent someone to request of the Empress Dowager: "This is not something a person would do.

s0097: In the third year, there were no events.

s0099: When the daughter of Marquis of Xuanping was Empress of Emperor Xiaohui, she had no son; pretending to be pregnant, she took a beautiful woman's son, named him, killed his mother, and installed the named son as Crown Prince.
s0100: Emperor Xiaohui died; the Crown Prince was installed as Emperor.
s0101: When the emperor grew up, someone told him his mother had died and he was not the true empress's son; he then spoke out, saying: "How could the empress kill my mother and name me?
s0102: I am not yet grown; when I am grown I will make changes."
s0103: The Empress Dowager heard this and was troubled by it; fearing he would create disorder, she imprisoned him in the Eternal Coils, said the emperor was severely ill, and none of those around him could see him.
s0104: The Empress Dowager said: "Those who possess all under Heaven and govern as the fate of the ten thousand people should cover them like Heaven and contain them like Earth; above having a joyful heart to comfort the hundred clans, the hundred clans delighting to serve their superior, joy and delight flowing between them and all under Heaven governed.
s0105: Now the emperor's illness has long not ceased; he has lost awareness and is confused and disordered, unable to continue succession to offer at the ancestral temples—all under Heaven cannot be entrusted to him; he should be replaced."
s0106: The assembled ministers all kowtowed and said: "The Empress Dowager on behalf of the common people of all under Heaven plans for the security of the ancestral temples and altars of soil and grain very deeply; the assembled ministers kowtow and receive the edict."
s0107: The emperor was deposed; the Empress Dowager imprisoned and killed him.
s0108: On the bingchen day of the fifth month, they installed King Yi of Changshan as Emperor and changed his name to Hong.
s0109: They did not call it the first year because the Empress Dowager controlled the affairs of all under Heaven.

s0114: In summer, they pardoned all under Heaven.
s0115: They enfeoffed King Daohui of Qi's son Xingju as Marquis of Dongmou.
s0116: In the first month of the seventh year, the Empress Dowager summoned King You of Zhao.
s0117: You had taken a daughter of the various Lü as queen but did not love her, loving another consort; the Lü daughter was jealous, angrily departed, and slandered him to the Empress Dowager, falsely accusing him of crimes, saying: "How can the Lü obtain kingship!
s0118: After the Empress Dowager's hundred years, I will certainly strike them."
s0119: The Empress Dowager was angry and consequently summoned the King of Zhao.
s0120: When the King of Zhao arrived, they placed him in a residence and would not see him, ordered guards to surround and watch him, and would not give him food.
s0121: Some of his assembled ministers secretly brought food; they would immediately arrest and prosecute them; the King of Zhao, starving, then sang: "The various Lü handle affairs and the Liu clan is endangered; they coerce kings and marquises and forcibly gave me a consort.
s0122: My consort being jealous slandered me with wickedness; slanderous women disorder the state and the superior never awakens.
s0123: I have no loyal ministers—why should I abandon my state?
s0124: I will end myself in the wilderness—may Heaven raise up the upright!
s0125: Alas, it cannot be undone—better to have ended myself earlier.
s0126: To be a king and starve to death—who will pity this!
s0127: The Lü clan cuts off principle—I entrust Heaven to take revenge."
s0128: On the dingchou day, the King of Zhao died imprisoned; they buried him with commoner's rites in the commoner tomb grounds of Chang'an.
s0129: On the jichou day, there was a solar eclipse with darkness at midday.
s0130: The Empress Dowager took this as a bad omen, was unhappy in her heart, and said to those around her: "This is because of me."
s0132: In the second month, they moved King Hui of Liang to be King of Zhao.

s0134: They installed the imperial son Marquis of Pingchang Tai as King of Lü.

s0138: When King Hui of Liang was moved to be King of Zhao, his heart harbored unhappiness.
s0139: The Empress Dowager made Lü Chan's daughter Queen of Zhao.

s0142: The king then composed four chapters of songs and poems and had musicians sing them.

s0145: Marquis of Xuanping Zhang Ao died; they made his son Yan King of Lu and bestowed on Ao the posthumous title King Lu Yuan.

s0151: In the tenth month of the eighth year, they installed King Su of Lü's son Marquis of Dongping Lü Tong as King of Yan and enfeoffed Tong's younger brother Lü Zhuang as Marquis of Dongping.

s0154: The High Empress then fell ill from the armpit wound.
s0155: The High Empress's external grandson King Yan of Lu Yuan was young, having lost his parents early, isolated and weak; she then enfeoffed Zhang Ao's former consort's two sons—Chi as Marquis of Xindu and Shou as Marquis of Lechang—to assist King Yan of Lu Yuan.
s0156: She also enfeoffed Chief Herald Zhang Shi as Marquis of Jianling and Lü Rong as Marquis of Zhuzi.
s0157: All palace eunuch directors and assistants were made marquises within the passes, with estates of five hundred households.

s0233: The Grand Commandant rose and bowed in congratulation to Marquis of Zhuxu, saying: "What we feared was only Lü Chan; now he has been executed, all under Heaven is settled."
s0234: They then sent men to divide into sections to completely arrest all Lü males and females; none, young or old, were spared—all were beheaded.
s0235: On the xinyou day, they arrested and beheaded Lü Lu and flogged Lü Xu to death.
s0236: They sent men to execute King Lü Tong of Yan and deposed King Yan of Lu.
s0237: On the renxu day, they made Grand Tutor of the Emperor Yiji again Left Prime Minister.
s0238: On the wuchen day, they moved King of Jichuan to rule Liang and installed the son of King You of Zhao, Sui, as King of Zhao.
s0239: They sent Marquis of Zhuxu Zhang to inform the King of Qi of the matter of executing the various Lü clan and ordered him to dismiss his troops.
s0240: Guan Ying's troops also dismissed from Yingyang and returned.
s0241: The various great ministers secretly plotted together, saying: "The young emperor and the kings of Liang, Huaiyang, and Changshan are all not truly sons of Emperor Xiaohui.
s0242: Empress Lü by stratagem deceitfully named other people's sons, killed their mothers, raised them in the rear palace, had Emperor Xiaohui claim them as sons, and installed them as heirs and as the various kings to strengthen the Lü clan.
s0243: Now we have already exterminated all the various Lü, yet if we keep those who were installed and they grow up to handle affairs, we will have no posterity.
s0244: It would be better to examine which of the kings is most worthy and install him."
s0245: Some said: "King Daohui of Qi was the High Emperor's eldest son; now his legitimate son is King of Qi; tracing it to the origin, he is the High Emperor's legitimate eldest grandson and can be installed."
s0246: The great ministers all said: "The Lü clan as external family were wicked and nearly endangered the ancestral temples, disordering the meritorious ministers; now the King of Qi's maternal family is Sijun—Sijun are wicked people.
s0247: If we install the King of Qi, it will again become like the Lü clan."
s0248: They wished to install the King of Huainan but considered him young and his maternal family also wicked.
s0249: They then said: "The King of Dai is presently the High Emperor's surviving son, the eldest, benevolent, filial, generous, and magnanimous.
s0250: The Grand Empress's family, the Bo clan, are careful and good.
s0251: Moreover, installing the eldest follows proper order; as he is known for benevolence and filial piety throughout all under Heaven, it is convenient."
s0252: They then together secretly sent men to summon the King of Dai.
s0253: The King of Dai sent men to decline and express thanks.
s0254: After going back and forth twice, he then rode in six relay chariots.
s0255: On the last day of the ninth month, the jiyou day, he reached Chang'an and lodged at the Dai residence.
s0256: The great ministers all went to pay respects, presented the Son of Heaven's seal to the King of Dai, and together honored and installed him as Son of Heaven.
s0257: The King of Dai declined several times; the assembled ministers firmly requested, and then he listened.
s0258: Marquis of Dongmou Xingju said: "In executing the Lü clan I had no merit; I request to be allowed to purge the palace."
s0259: He then with Grand Coachman Marquis of Ruyin Duke Teng entered the palace, went before the young emperor and said: "You are not of the Liu clan and should not be installed."
s0260: He then looked back and gestured to those around holding halberds to lay down their weapons and withdraw.
s0261: Several men refused to lay down their weapons; Eunuch Commander Zhang Ze instructed and informed them, and they also laid down their weapons.
s0262: Duke Teng then summoned the imperial chariot to carry the young emperor out.
s0263: The young emperor said: "Where do you wish to take me?"
s0264: Duke Teng said: "Going out to your residence."
s0265: They lodged him at the Junior Supervisor's.
s0266: They then presented the Son of Heaven's ceremonial procession and welcomed the King of Dai at the residence.
s0267: They reported: "The palace has been carefully purged."
s0268: The King of Dai that very evening entered Weiyang Palace.
s0269: There were ten heralds holding halberds defending the端 Gate who said: "The Son of Heaven is within—who are you and why do you enter?"
s0270: The King of Dai then addressed the Grand Commandant.
s0271: The Grand Commandant went to instruct them; the ten heralds all laid down their weapons and departed.
s0272: The King of Dai then entered and attended to government.
s0273: By night, the officials divided into sections to execute and exterminate the kings of Liang, Huaiyang, and Changshan as well as the young emperor at their residences.
s0274: The King of Dai was installed as Son of Heaven.
s0275: After twenty-three years he died; his posthumous title was Emperor Xiaowen.
s0276: The Grand Historian says: In the time of Emperor Xiaohui and the High Empress, the common people were able to leave behind the suffering of the Warring States; lords and ministers both wished to rest in non-action, therefore Emperor Hui folded his hands and垂拱, the High Empress as female lord held power, governance did not leave the chambers, and all under Heaven was tranquil.
s0277: Punishments were rarely used; criminals were few.
s0278: The people focused on agriculture; clothing and food grew abundant.
